To the opposite extreme, students may voice arguments that “we are now like local private schools that enforce strict, religious guidelines.” With regard to depth, a singular controversial decision by the principal to control the decency of dance attendees could implode. For example, the superintendent could have received numerous complaints about the principal’s frequent choice to take a moral stand on several issues. To reduce political friction, the principal’s choice to set high standards for the dance may be the final event that compels the superintendent to offer reprimand and/or seek the principal’s resignation. Although arguably superficial, the stance taken by the principal may be emblematic of deeper concerns that the school district has counseled the principal about over an extended tenure.

Resources—capacity building; social capital; unobstructed view; barrier breaking: wisdom gained through experience allows an astute principal to begin generating capacities for success—well in advance of incidents like dances. Perhaps students are required to take classical dancing lessons during PE class in anticipation of the traditional “nostalgia homecoming dance” that features only classical dancing, music, and accompanying environ. The principal generates social capital by allying with stakeholders who buy into a compelling vision. When detecting controversy, the principal might ask allies to intervene and help sell the vision as a higher priority than the issue being argued about. The leader has to take time away from the pragmatic demands of work to ascend to a perch high enough to recapture the big picture. By obtaining an unobstructed view of the school’s needs, the value of school dances, possible fallout from the decision to restrict grinding, and the virtues of taking a moral stand, a leader may gain clarity. Additionally, such an inventory can also expose barriers to be breached (e.g., groups of disgruntled vocal parents, upset students who think their rights have been violated, a superintendent who has issued the ultimatum that “if I get one more complaint from your school . . .”).

Aviation terms—attitude; pitch; yaw; velocity; drag; lift; altitude: for a principal who has spent time establishing rapport, mutual respect, and trust among school stakeholders, there may be more allowance for and tolerance of directives and policy setting. Success when leading thus far may grant an incumbent leader some professional courtesy when setting a dance standard. The challenge for a new leader is to carefully assess the aviation terms, virtually, prior to implementing change. A quick survey of subjective attitudes among PTO/PTA, student government, and faculty regarding grinding may identify a prevailing attitude that informs the “directional attitude” a leader assumes. Directional attitude is the posture a leader must take in order to operate (e.g., authoritarian, democratic, collaborative). The pitch in this case is how intense the principal makes the argument; requesting versus requiring that grinding not occur. Yaw relates to a leader’s juxtaposition of dance etiquette to overall moral appropriateness. Can taking a stance regarding the dance serve to establish a level of moral expectations school-wide? Velocity is associated with how fast the principal introduced the moral standard. If published in a handbook early in the year, the impact at Homecoming time may be reduced. Comparatively, if there is a sign posted at the dance entry door stating “NO GRINDING,” the shock of the rule’s implementation may cause inertia. Inertia can become drag when angry and disgruntled students and parents want to gain control and power back. The principal may be fighting multiple wars (e.g., issues of control, fairness, distorted rationale, rebellion, insubordination) as students enter into the dance. A wise leader would have provided lift earlier in the year when recognizing students, engaging them in profound learning experiences, emphasizing the value of moral standards, and so on. Lift, in the form of affirmations and affordances, may take the school to a higher altitude of operating expectations. If successful, the principal would have invited stakeholders to embrace a set of standards that framed the emerging self as virtuous and decent. That said, rules that indicate no grinding would be acceptable and supported.

Frame, bias, experience, priority, urgency, and error: These factors are conscious checking opportunities for the leader. To enter a leading opportunity “not knowing what you don’t know” can result in disaster. A leader needs to identify her/his perceptions of self, versus those of the organization in which the leading is being attempted. A seasoned leader can assess these same dynamics for subgroups (i.e., Board, teacher’s union, community stakeholders) by proactively facilitating dialogue. The result can be demystifying when divergence from a common vision is identified and addressed prior to negative impact on the organizations’ compass heading and leader’s effectiveness.

Micropolitics—tide; current; temperature; prevailing wind, jet stream, weather, and time of day: Of all dynamics in the Oriented Compass Model, these are powerful, high impact dynamics that a leader should consider carefully. Relative to the case study scenario, “tide” is a sense of the majority’s perception (not necessarily their actual thoughts and feelings). Homecoming is one of the high school traditions that is heavy in sentiment. What was a passive year is suddenly energized with new relationships occurring, bitter disappointments, awkwardness, festivities, radical changes to schedules, and other extremes. Rules are modified to accommodate the rising tide of energy and excitement. The current that runs through the tide can be derived from popular fashion trends, social networking, and taboo subject matter, which is often neglected in parent-child discussions about drinking, sexual activity, and malicious pranks. Temperature relates to co-occurring issues that a leader must confront. Certain community events may taint the homecoming event positively (homecoming parade through town) and negatively (not being selected to be on homecoming court or not being asked to the dance). Issues may manifest as absence from school, fights, and even suicide. Prevailing wind can be considered a temporary trend. Perhaps, the guys get their ears pierced or get tattoos resulting from social status pressure. Of greater concern is the trend of getting drunk or high prior to the dance since “everyone else is doing it.” The literature refers to an adolescent’s imaginary audience that approves choices even though that audience only exists in the adolescent’s mind.

sec.p: Akin to the prevailing wind but of greater substance is the jet stream. A leader has to calculate what resources are needed to confront a strong head wind (e.g., fierce resistance), a powerful tail wind (e.g., catalyzed reactions to rules), and the effects of taking a moral stance off course (e.g., generalizing the moral stance of no grinding to other school rules, such as how close a student stands to another in the lunch line). Weather is a broader concept that takes into account, for example, a forecast and the ability to prepare for conditions. A veteran principal knows that backlash is part of the job when controversial decisions are made. Like clouds and storms, discontent will pass or angry students/families will withdraw and attend elsewhere, choose homeschooling, or pay tuition for a private alternative.

Finally, time of day is significant. Decisions made in the light of day (transparently) are desired. However, a leader’s decision making may occur at off hours depending on circumstances. For example, implementing a rule that disallows grinding at dances may have been a decision made by the School Board after a vote. The public only sees the principal’s directive indicating that a rule is now in place. When decisions are made without the opportunity to be transparent, a leader can provide rationale and warrants that scaffold reasons for the decision. Stakeholders may not agree but could comply based on the fairness and cohesiveness of the argument presented. In the above, special attention must be paid to the relationships operating within and among each stakeholder. If a leader maintains relationships appropriately, transparently, and in keeping with phronesis (doing what is right for society), the micropolitical dynamic should remain in the leader’s control.

Conducting a transparent and well-communicated process does not guarantee that parents will be happy with the principal’s decision to enact a rule. However, it does provide the leader (in this case study—the principal) with a process to use when demystifying situations, determining an appropriate course of action to take, and enhancing his/her own situational awareness when using a logical model and mining for artifacts that confirm or deny effective leading. However, the leader and leading are not of highest importance. Applying the Oriented Compass Model can serve as a checks and balance system for increasing the potential of leadership outcomes—as derived from the leader-led relationship.

bio.title: Bio
bio.p: Paul D. Fallon is a former Captain in the U.S. Marine Corps, regional superintendent of schools, principal, teacher, and crisis counselor. At the time of this manuscript’s acceptance, he was preparing to defend a doctoral dissertation within the Education and Policy Studies Department at University at Albany, SUNY. Paul Fallon is the owner of True North Ventures, LLC; an educational consulting company focused on vision and mission development with school Boards and crisis planning/training for school systems.
